results.title: Play School. Special; Concert
results.brief_description: Appearing in the “Play school special” are eight well-loved Play school presenters: Benita Collings, Merridy Eastman, John Hamblin, Noni Hazelhurst, Jennifer Ludlum, Philip Quast, Don Spencer and John Waters. Favourite songs include ‘Old Macdonald’, ‘Baa baa black sheep’, ‘The paper song’, ‘There’s a bear in there’ and many more. Some of the stories are ‘Harry the dirty dog’, ‘There was a princess’ and ‘The hole’. Benita Collings and John Hamblin perform in a Play School concert. The audience joins in with the words and actions of popular Play school songs. Among them are ‘I’m a little teapot’ and ‘Bananas in pyjamas’.

results.title: Play school. Out and about
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Henrietta Clark and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Play School in these two programs goes to the beach and spends a day in the Botanic Gardens. Both programs feature songs and stories about the beach and the botanic gardens. Presenters include Colin Buchanan, John Hamblin, Don Spencer and Monica Trapaga.

results.title: Play School. Hats
results.brief_description: In these five episodes of Play School, John Hamblin and Noni Hazelhurst have lots of fun with all kinds of hats. They make hats, they wear hats and they tell stories and sing about the people who wear them. Songs include “Do you put your hat on your head?”, “Three little fishes”, “Wiggerly Woo”, “Hey diddle diddle” and others. Some of the delightful stories are Mrs. Honey’s Hat, Jonathan Just and the Quangle Wangle’s Hat. In all, two and a half hours of wonderful entertainment for children.

results.title: Play school. Dinosaurs
results.brief_description: What was it like when dinosaurs were alive? This fascinating program provides an entertaining way for children to understand more about the prehistoric world. Children will be captivated by stories, activities and songs which tell of a world long ago.

results.title: Play School meets the orchestra
results.brief_description: Nine Play School presenters appear in this video which explores the world of music, sound and making music. Featuring the Sydney Symphony Orchestra conducted by Roland Peelman.

results.title: Play Safe
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Video Films and Australian Road Safety Council
results.brief_description: Aimed at children, this film highlights a number of road safety aspects. Don Bradman talks to the children about avoiding accidents, both going and coming from school, and during playtime on the school playground.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation
MOV file H264; ACMI External Digital Access Copy

results.title: Play Loud
results.brief_description:
The distinctive Australian ‘pub rock’ sound was born in the hotels and bars of our major cities in the 1970s.
In the Melbourne scene, the ‘beer barns’ of the suburbs were complemented by smaller, more intimate venues in the city and inner suburbs of Carlton, Richmond, Fitzroy and St Kilda.
This film - made in his student days by award-winning producer Daniel Scharf - presents a 1979 performance by the Melbourne band ‘Cuban Heels’ at one such venue, ‘Hearts’ in Carlton.
The atmosphere of alcohol, cigarette-smoke and youthful exuberance is captured by the camera as it wanders through the audience and lingers on the dancers.
On stage, the band (led by Steve Connolly, who was later the guitarist with Paul Kelly’s ‘Coloured Girls’ and ‘Messengers’ bands) sings a song that could only be a product of the 1970s - about ‘the system’ and the coming revolution.

This film - made in his student days by award-winning producer Daniel Scharf - presents a 1979 performance by the Melbourne band ‘Cuban Heels’ at one such venue, ‘Hearts’ in Carlton.
The atmosphere of alcohol, cigarette-smoke and youthful exuberance is captured by the camera as it wanders through the audience and lingers on the dancers.
On stage, the band (led by Steve Connolly, who was later the guitarist with Paul Kelly’s ‘Coloured Girls’ and ‘Messengers’ bands) sings a song that could only be a product of the 1970s - about ‘the system’ and the coming revolution.

results.title: Play-clay
results.creator_credit: Mary Anna Winkler, Peter Erik Winkler and ACI Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “At Your Fingertips”.
Shows how flour, salt and water can be combined to make an inexpensive modelling clay. Explains how to make and decorate various things with it. Suitable for lower and upper primary levels.

group_siblings.title: Boxes (TEFC)
group_siblings.creator_credit: Mary Anna Winkler, Peter Erik Winkler and ACI Films

results.title: Boxes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mary Anna Winkler, Peter Erik Winkler and ACI Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “At Your Fingertips”.
Shows a number of things that can be made by children from boxes which originally held house-hold items. Cereal boxes covered with paper and coloured become a model village; milk cartons are made into cars or trains or animals. The biggest cartons, such as those in which refrigerators are delivered, appear as a truck, with two boys as the motive power, delivering to a playhouse. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: Cylinders (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “At Your Fingertips”.
Designed to help children become aware of the creative possibilities of the cylindrical shape. Using readily available materials found in the home, children create an assortment of play things, models, sculptures and screens.
